iati-activity.reporting-org: The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria
iati-activity.title: Sealing up Malaria Interventions to Achieve Universal Coverage
iati-activity.description: Malaria is the leading cause of morbidity and mortality in Malawi and it accounts for 38 percent on all Out-Patient Department (OPD) attendance. The Malaria inpatient death rate is 20 percent in under 5 years and 3 percent in those over 5 years of age. According to Malawi’s Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey in 2006, 21 percent of the population have access to anti-malarial drugs within 24 hours.. The Insecticide Treated Nets (ITNs) usage was at 24.7 percent and 25.6 percent for children under five and pregnant women respectively. The program supported by this grant focuses on the diagnosis of suspected Malaria cases with rapid diagnostic tests and distribution of Long Lasting Insecticide Nets (LLINs) as these are major gaps identified and in line with universal access to Malaria interventions. The goal is to reduce the burden of Malaria to a level of no public health significance and to achieve universal coverage for all Malaria control interventions, particularly diagnosis and prevention. The activities include procurement, distribution, and storage of LLINs, community mobilization, and behaviour change communication.

contact-info.organisation: The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria

iati-activity.participating-org: The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria
Ministry of Health of Malawi

conditions.condition: the written approval by the Global Fund of the appointment of the Selected Procurement Agent made by the Principal Recipient.

1. Condition(s) Precedent to the Second Disbursement (Terminal Date as stated in block 6A of the Face Sheet) Without prejudice to Articles 4 and 28 of the Standard Terms and Conditions of this Agreement, the second disbursement of Grant funds shall be subject to the delivery to the Global Fund and the Principal Recipients, which the Principal Recipient will use to minimize cash transactions during implementation of this Grant and any impediment of bank transfers from the Principal Recipient to tis Sub-Recipients or directly to the employees or contractors ("personnel") of its Sub-recipients, including with respect to any applicable domestic taxes of withholdings on salaries, and to mitigate all direct and indirect risks for both the Principal Recipient and the Global Fund. For the avoidance of any doubt, the Global Fund acknowledges that the Principal Recipient shall not be responsible for any domestic taxes or withholding on salaries that are not imposed on, or payable by the Principal Recipient. Without prejudice to Article 10(b) of the Standard Terms and Conditions of this Agreement, the Principal Recipient shall obtain and maintain in effect a continuing certification effective until the termination of this Agreement from each of its Sub-recipients, that such Sub-recipients complies with all relevant domestic and international laws, including, but not limited to, labour and taxation laws, with respect to the personnel of the Sub-recipient.

Special Condition 1. By July 2012, and in accordance with Article 10(b) of the Standard Terms and Conditions of this Agreement, the Principal Recipient shall submit to the Global Fund in form and substance satisfactory to the Global Fund a written report establishing that an electronic monitoring system for recording, analysis and reporting on the periodic results for indicators on Most-at-Risk Populations reached with HIV prevention services financed under the Grant Agreement has been implemented and is fully functional.

Special Condition 2. Pursuant to Article 2 of the Standard Terms and Conditions of this Agreement, the Principal Recipient will implement or oversee the implementation of the Program using its regulations, rules and procedures; access to the Principal Recipient’s internal audit reports is governed by the disclosure policy adopted by its Executive Board (EB decision 2008/37 of 19 September 2008) and is currently limited to United Nations Member States.

Special Condition 3. Within three months of the issue date of an LFA assessment of the capacity of a national entity (or other relevant entity) in relation to the assumption of the role of principal recipient of this grant, the Principal Recipient shall deliver to the Global Fund a plan in form and substance satisfactory to the Global Fund, detailing the measures to be financed under this Agreement to be undertaken to strengthen the controls and systems relating to the Program and build the capacity of the national principal recipient candidate (or other relevant entity), and detailing handover arrangements (including without limitation submitting an appropriate exit plan for the Program). The Principal Recipient shall carry out such exit plan, in consultation with the CCM, national principal recipient candidate ( or other relevant entity) and the Global Fund.

B-CONDITIONS PRECEDENT TO DISBURSEMENT
1. Condition(s) Precedent to Disbursement or Use of Grant Funds to Finance the Procurement of Health and other Non-Health Products (Terminal Date as stated in block 7 A of the Face Sheet) The disbursement of funds for the procurement of health and other relevant products shall be subject to the delivery by the Principal Recipient to the Global Fund of evidence, in form and substance satisfactory to the Global Fund, that it has selected and contracted a suitably qualified Procurement Agent under terms and reference acceptable to the Global Fund.

2. Condition(s) Precedent to Disbursement or Use of Grant Funds to Finance the Procurement of Second-Line Anti-TB Drugs (Terminal Date as stated in block 7B of the Face Sheet)
The disbursement by the Global Fund or use by the Principal Recipient of Grant funds to finance the procurement of second-line anti-tuberculosis drugs is subject to the satisfaction of each of the following conditions: a) A detailed multi-drug resistant tuberculosis ("MDR-TB") expansion plan, including the number of MDR-TB patients to be treated, and the national guidelines for programmatic management of MDR-TB, both of which have been developed in collaboration with a technical partner acceptable to the Global Fund

The PR shall submit, in form and substance satisfactory to the Global Fund, a revised Phase 2 Procurement Plan with and updated Country Profile (Part I and Part II). The PR shall provide finalized quantification based on national need and ensure that the Procurement Plan is consistent with the Work-plan & Budget and that all assumptions used to determine the quantities of health products are clearly documented, including, where applicable, the link to the targets in the Performance Framework. The PR shall also provide all the rationale behind the PSM cost and update / revise unit prices of health products. The procurement arrangement proposed for Phase 2 should be clearly defined and agreed with the CCM.

The PR is requested to submit a revised and updated Monitoring and Evaluation (M&E) Plan which has been approved by the Global Fund for the next implementation period which is aligned with the approved performance framework for the next implementation period.  The M&E Plan should include the following:

(i.) clear target assumptions for all activities in the next implementation period, taking into account average performance ratios for each indicators in the previous implementation period
(ii.) an action plan to implement recommendations from the OSDV
(iii.) provide a clear division of labour for any activity that is implemented by more than one PR
(iv.) demonstrate how the program will improve data collection and reporting for quality control missions at regional level and supervisions at district level
The Principal Recipient shall provide written feedback at each Progress Update on the implementation status of each recommendation arising from the OSDVs.

The Principal Recipient shall provide evidence, in form and substance satisfactory to the Global Fund, that measures are in place to ensure that the per diem policy as described in the Manual of Procedures is respected by the Principal Recipient and Sub-Recipients and that expenses are accompanied by adequate documentation.

The Principal Recipient shall provide, in form and substance satisfactory to the Global Fund, a maintenance plan for the equipment purchase through grant funds. and provide evidence during grant implementation that this plan is adequately implemented

The use of Grant funds by the Principal Recipient, Sub-recipients or Sub-sub-recipients for the payment of incentives and salaries of the employees shall be subject to each of the following conditions being met in form and substance satisfactory to the Global Fund:

(i.) Delivery by the Principal Recipient to the Global Fund of a Salary and Incentive Scheme, in form and substance satisfactory to the Global Fund, demonstrating the link between the incentives and Program performance, identifying the staff members eligible for incentives, demonstrating that there is no duplication of salary and/or incentives paid from Grant funds to any individual and demonstrating that the scheme is in line with the practice followed by other donors in the Country;
(ii.) Delivery by the Principal Recipient to the Global Fund of written endorsement by the Country Coordinating Mechanism (CCM) of the Salary and Incentives Scheme; and
(iii.) Written approval of the Salary and Incentive Scheme by the Global Fund;

The Global Fund shall exercise full discretion with respect to reinvestment of savings due to revision of salaries/incentives in accordance with the Salary and Incentives Scheme.

The Principal Recipient and the CNLS shall submit jointly to the Global Fund  a review of BCC activities and Care and support activities for PLWHA and OVCs implemented in Phase 1 and an action plan for the Next Implementation Period, comprising of the following:

(i.) Description of BCC activities to be implemented that are comprised of high impact interventions in line with international technical guidelines and which demonstrate a clear division of tasks between PRs and avoid double-counting of results data

(ii.) Care and support activities for PLWHA and OVCs which better target beneficiaries most in need and demonstrate a clear division of labour and coordination of activities between PRs.  Care and support activities should have clear entry and exit criteria and should demonstrate a clear link to treatment activities.

(iii.) Detailed explanation of the scope, approach, measurement, and reporting for all BCC and care and support activities, with a clear description of which PR is implementing which activities by region and clear selection criteria for determining program beneficiaries. The Principal Recipients and Sub-Recipients shall seek to harmonize unit costs at the most efficient level for the implementation of these interventions.

(iv.) Definition of the minimum package of prevention services for MARPs, namely sex workers, men who have sex with men, and injecting drug users.  The components of the identified standard prevention package should be included in the performance framework for the next implementation period and used to inform MARPs-related indicators. The review should describe the approach to reach MARPs and involve them in program design and implementation.

The Principal Recipient shall submit to the Global Fund a complete mapping of the Sub-Recipients (SRs) and Sub-Sub-Recipients (SSRs) involved in the implementation of Phase 1 the grant, including their location (region, town or village covered) and the services provided. The Principal Recipient shall propose a reduction in the number of SRs and SSRs to be contracted for the next Implementation Period that will permit adequate oversight by the Principal Recipient while still achieving programmatic goals. The final number of SRs and SSRs shall be approved by the Global Fund .

The Global Fund shall exercise full discretion with respect to reinvestment of savings due to the reduction in the number of SRs and SSRs for the implementation of Phase 2.

The Principal Recipient shall provide a revised Manual of Procedures, in form and substance satisfactory to the Global Fund, that describes that systems in place to adequately monitor financial management of SRs and SSRs (e.g. accounting software, standardized financial tools to be used by all SRs/SSR, increased PR monitoring visits to SR and SRs to SSRs, role of the internal auditor, defining role of ANCS regional focal points in follow up of SSRs, etc.)

The PR shall ensure the continuity of implementation of these procedures during the next Implementation Period, and report on these in each PU/DR.

The Principal Recipient shall provide evidence, in form and substance satisfactory to the Global Fund, that the Principal Recipient has installed an Integrated Financial Management and Accounting system (software), including modules in budgeting, accounting, and cash management and, if available, an asset management and tracking tool, and fully incorporating Sub-Recipients disbursement and expenditures.  has provided adequate training on using the accounting software to the appropriate staff members.

The Principal Recipient shall establish an Internal Audit Plan (IAP) in form and substance satisfactory to the Global Fund and provide evidence to the Global Fund that the IAP is in effect and operational. The IAP must include a detailed program for financial monitoring of all Sub-recipients and require a report to be prepared and submitted quarterly as part of the Principal Recipient’s periodic reporting to the Global Fund.

The Principal Recipient shall reimburse the Global Fund grant funds overpaid and should demonstrate that the following actions have been done during the remaining time of the implementation period:

• Reimburse amounts paid above budget

The PR should ensure the continuity of implementation of those actions, and report in each PU/DR the evidence of them during the phase 2 period.

The Principal Recipient shall deliver to the Global Fund, in form and substance satisfactory to the Global Fund, a revised PSM plan. The PSM plan shall address concerns regarding procurement, Inventory Management and Quality Assurance. The PSM Plan shall be consistent with the work plan & budget and all assumptions used shall be clearly documented, including, where applicable, the link to the targets in the Performance Framework.

The Principal Recipient shall deliver to the Global Fund, in form and substance satisfactory to the Global Fund:
1) evidence that CAME tender documentation has been reviewed in line with ACAME recommendations and templates, with the support of technical assistance if needed; and
2)  An executed copy of a revised MoU between the CAME and the NTP which shall clearly define the responsibilities of each party in the timely procurement of quality pharmaceuticals and health products compliant with the Global Fund Quality Assurance Policy.

iati-activity.reporting-org: The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria
iati-activity.title: Towards Sustainable and Equitable Tuberculosis Control
iati-activity.description: The program supported by this grant aims to reduce the burden of ill health due to TB in Malawi by pursuing high-quality DOTS expansion and enhancement; addressing infection control, MDR-TB and TB/HIV co-infection; engaging all care providers; and enabling and promoting operational research. Grant funds will be used to mobilize communities to seek treatment; establish sputum collection centers in communities; provide high-burden laboratories in district hospitals with fluorescent microscopes; conduct a TB prevalence survey and an MDR-TB survey; and establish an electronic TB register in existing TB registration sites. The program targets the general population, civil society, people living with HIV and AIDS; and TB patients and former TB patients.

contact-info.organisation: The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria

iati-activity.participating-org: The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria
Ministry of Health of Malawi

conditions.condition: Prior to the disbursement by the Global Fund to the Principal Recipient of Grant funds to finance the procurement of second-line anti-tuberculosis drugs, the Principal Recipient shall make available to the Global Fund, in form and substance satisfactory to the Global Fund, the following: a. A current detailed multi-drug resistant tuberculosis ("MDR-TB") expansion plan (including the number of MDR-TB patients to be treated and the list and quantifications of the medicines to be procured for the MDR-TB program reflecting the Principal Recipient’s finalized forecast for the grant implementation period covered by the Grant ) and the national guidelines for programmatic management of MDR-TB, both of which have been developed in collaboration with a technical partner acceptable to the Global Fund; and b. For each disbursement request that includes funds for the procurement of MDR-TB medicines, a pro forma invoice issued by the designated Procurement Agent of the Global Drug Facility, as delegated by the Green Light Committee Initiative.

The disbursement of Grant funds by the Global Fund to the Principal Recipient for the purpose of paying the salaries of the following job positions is subject to the Principal Recipient delivering to the Global Fund and to its satisfaction, a report of the applicable grades and comparison with the relevant government salary scales from the Ministry of Public Service for the same or similar job positions. c. Executive Secretary - Stop TB Partnership. d. Capacity Building Officer - Stop TB Partnership . e. Communications Officer - Stop TB Partnership . f. Nurse Assistant to Conduct Community TB screening and treatment support by Cabrini Ministry. g. Central Medical Stores Chief Executive Officer ("CMS CEO") Salary and Gratuity. The disbursement of Grant funds to pay for professional fees for CMS CEO Evaluation and grading costs is subject to the delivery of documentation, satisfactory to the Global Fund, supporting the cost of the aforementioned fees.

The Principal Recipient shall deliver to the Global Fund, in form and substance satisfactory to the Global Fund, a revised PSM plan. The PSM plan shall address concerns regarding procurement, Inventory Management and Quality Assurance. The PSM Plan shall be consistent with the work plan & budget and all assumptions used shall be clearly documented, including, where applicable, the link to the targets in the Performance Framework.

The Principal Recipient shall deliver to the Global Fund, in form and substance satisfactory to the Global Fund:
1) evidence that CAME tender documentation has been reviewed in line with ACAME recommendations and templates, with the support of technical assistance if needed; and
2)  An executed copy of a revised MoU between the CAME and the NTP which shall clearly define the responsibilities of each party in the timely procurement of quality pharmaceuticals and health products compliant with the Global Fund Quality Assurance Policy.

The Principal Recipient shall deliver to the Global Fund, in form and substance satisfactory to the Global Fund, a Quality Assurance Plan (QAP). The QAP shall clearly describe the measures to be taken to monitor and ensure the quality of pharmaceuticals, from the moment of purchase to consumption by the end user. A work plan and a budget should be added. The QA budget should be based on 3% of the EwX drug costs (QC budget around 1%). This line should be included in the detailed budget.

iati-activity.reporting-org: The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria
iati-activity.title: HIV Cross Border Initiative
iati-activity.description: The Southern African Development Community (SADC) is a fifteen member regional intergovernmental organization aimed at increasing regional socio-economic integration, intended to yield greater economic growth and poverty alleviation. Its member states include Angola, Botswana, Democratic Republic of the Congo, Lesotho, Malawi, Mozambique, Mauritius, Namibia, Seychelles, South Africa, Swaziland, Tanzania, Zambia and Zimbabwe. SADC covers a region where over one-third of all people living with HIV reside, and accost where almost one-third of all new HIV infections and one-third of AIDS-related deaths occur. This grant aims to reduce HIV infections in the SADC region and to mitigate the impact of HIV and AIDS on mobile populations and affected communities across member states. The program activities include facilitation of cooperation agreements amongst facilities at border sites to support mobile populations, development of standards, guidelines and protocols for patient follow-up and referral mechanisms, standardization of case detection and reporting systems and development of a study on Sexually Transmitted Infection (STI) continuum of care.

contact-info.organisation: The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria

iati-activity.participating-org: The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria
Southern African Development Community

conditions.condition:
SPECIAL TERMS AND CONDITIONS FOR THIS AGREEMENT
1. The Principal Recipient acknowledges and agrees that the requirement under Article 14 of the Standard Terms and Conditions of this Agreement that the Principal Recipient provide, not later than 90 days after this Agreement enters into force, a plan for monitoring the Program, is replaced with the condition precedent to second disbursement described in Section B.1 above.

SPECIAL TERMS AND CONDITIONS FOR THIS AGREEMENT
2. The parties acknowledge that as of the date of the signature of this Agreement, the Global Fund has not approved the plan for the procurement, use and supply management of Health Products (the "PSM Plan") consistent with Article 18 of the Standard Terms and Conditions of this Agreement. Consistent with such Standard Terms and Conditions, the disbursement by the Global Fund or use by the Principal Recipient of Grant funds for the procurement of Health Products is conditional upon the approval by the Global Fund of the PSM Plan.

SPECIAL TERMS AND CONDITIONS FOR THIS AGREEMENT
3. The Principal Recipient shall select Sub-recipients in accordance with its regulations and rules. Before disbursing grant funds to any Sub-recipient, the Principal Recipient shall notify the Global Fund of the selection of the Sub-recipient. In the case of a Sub-recipient that is not a UN agency, the Global Fund may, at its sole discretion, conduct an assessment of the Sub-recipient. The Principal Recipient shall address the assessment recommendations by risk mitigation measures satisfactory to both the Principal Recipient and the Global Fund.

SPECIAL CONDITION 7: 7. No later than 1 April 2012, the Principal Recipient shall provide to the Global Fund evidence, in form and substance satisfactory to the Global Fund, that the Principal Recipient’s internal control department responsible for the internal audit function is fully operational. By the same date, the Principal Recipient shall also provide evidence, in form and substance satisfactory to the Global Fund, that it has developed an internal audit plan validated by the CCM for the management of Grant funds, following which the internal audit reports and implementation of internal audit recommendations shall be submitted to the CCM and included as part of the regular progress updates to the Global Fund.

iati-activity.reporting-org: The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria
iati-activity.title: Health Systems Strengthening in Malawi
iati-activity.description: Malawi is one of the poorest countries in the world, where 65 percent of the population lives below the poverty line and more than half are food-insecure. This has a clear knock-on effect on Malawi’s health indicators, which are among the worst in Africa, and it also magnifies the impact of HIV and AIDS, TB and malaria. The program supported by this grant aims to strengthen the country’s capacity to fight AIDS, TB malaria primarily through improving its human resource infrastructure. Grant funds will be used to expand community-based HIV and AIDS, TB and malaria services by increasing the supply if highly skilled and motivated Health Surveillance Assistants; to increase other health sector human resource supply, such as community nurses and clinical officers, to carry out antiretroviral therapy and HIV and AIDS services as well as to meet other critical staffing gaps needed to provide full access to all health services; and to build the capacity of laboratory staff to meet the increasing demand for antiretroviral therapy.

contact-info.organisation: The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria

iati-activity.participating-org: The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria
Ministry of Health of Malawi

iati-activity.reporting-org: The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria
iati-activity.title: Intensifying HIV/AIDS Behavioral Change Communication (BCC) for all and Scaling up of HIV Prevention Services for Young People in Malawi
iati-activity.description:
1. Background and Summary
Malawi is among the countries in Southern Africa at the epicenter of the HIV/AIDS pandemic with HIV infection predominantly transmitted through heterosexual intercourse. Young people in Malawi constitute about 33% of the population and represent an age group with a high burden and high rate of new HIV infection. About 6% of young people aged between 15 and 24 years, 14% of pregnant young women of the same age group, and 14% of adults aged between 15 and 49 years are HIV infected. Women and young girls are more disproportionately affected than men; 13.3% of women infected compared to 10.2% of men. Urban rural disparities are also prominent, with 17.1% of urban residents infected compared to 10.8% of their rural counterparts. The prevalence of HIV infection caries across geographical regions from 17.6% in the worst affected regions in the northern part of the country compared to 6.5% in the least affected region.
The socio-demographic and economic consequence of over 20 years of the HIV pandemic in the country has been profound. For instance, life expectancy at birth today in Malawi is estimated at 39 years, having declined from 48 years in the early 1990’s and significantly less than the projected 54 years that it would have been in the absence of HIV/AIDS. AIDS now ranks among the three leading causes of death among adults in the country. The economic impact of the pandemic has profoundly reduced economic productivity. It has decimated the labour force for agriculture and manual work and critical skilled human capital required for the provision of health services, education and other development activities. The resources of the health sector have been strained by the added demand to provide care, treatment and prevention services for diverting scarce resources from other pressing health needs including child and maternal care. The health impact of the pandemic has been compounded by the re-emergence of the tuberculosis epidemic with currently an estimated 70% of people diagnosed with tuberculosis are co-infected with HIV. Tuberculosis is now the leading case of death among AIDS patients in the country. The social impact of AIDS has been profound and felt all over the country through death of family members, mainly men and women in the prime of their lives, leaving widows and orphans who often have to take over the care of their siblings and households. Schooling of children especially girls in such circumstances is interrupted and often terminated resulting in many children being out-of-school. Orphaned and out-of-school children are vulnerable to further HIV infection as they resort to hazardous activities such as sex work and living on the streets that further aggravate their vulnerability to HIV infection.
Malawi’s comprehensive multi-sectoral national response to the HIV/AIDS pandemic is currently based on the National HIV/AIDS Policy and outlined in the National HIV/AIDS Action Framework (NAF) 2005-2009. The coordination of the National HIV/AIDS Response is vested in the Principal Recipient a semi-autonomous body under the Office of the President and Cabinet (National Response). The NAF provides a framework for a comprehensive multi-sectoral HIV prevention and control strategies to guide all implementation partners in the country. The strategies are designed to address the pandemic in the context of its broader development challenges. This approach derives from and is consistent with the broader development framework of the country as outlined in the Malawi Growth and Development Strategy and the Malawi Vision 2020 and consistent with the Joint Program of Work for the Health Sector Wide Approach (2004-2010). Malawi has embraced the Millennium Development Goals of which Goal Number 6 aims to halt and reverse the spread of HIV by 2015, which is the NAF’s prevention goal.
The Program seeks to support the NAF by scaling up Behavioural Change Communication (BCC) interventions, HIV

contact-info.organisation: The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria

iati-activity.participating-org: The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria
National AIDS Commission, Malawi

conditions.condition: 4. Twelve months after the date by which the Global Fund has communicated its acceptance of the Health Product Management (HPM) Country Profile submitted by the Principal Recipient and every twelve months thereafter during the Program Term, the Principal Recipient shall update the HPM Country Profile, in consultation with the relevant government institutions, international partners and Sub-recipients. The Principal Recipient shall ensure that the information submitted in the HPM Country Profile is complete and accurate.

iati-activity.reporting-org: The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria
iati-activity.title: Scaling up Prevention and Treatment of Malaria within the Context of Essential Health Package and Sector-Wide Approach in Malawi
iati-activity.description: Malaria is a serious public health problem in Malawi, with the entire population being at risk for the disease. This grant is being used to finance a comprehensive set of activities within the context of the country’s health services. The funds will be used to subsidize the purchase and distribution of insecticide-treated bed nets for vulnerable groups, such as pregnant women and children under the age of five as well as the poorest of the poor. Distribution is being managed through antenatal and under-five clinics which are visited by more than 90 percent of pregnant women. In addition, community-based distribution will be strengthened through wide involvement of community committees, nongovernmental organizations and civil society. Grant funds will also be used to improve other important services such as case management through scaling up of integrated management of childhood illness; integrated disease surveillance; intermittent presumptive treatment; information, education and communication; operational research; and human resource development through training of health workers in areas relevant to malaria control.

iati-activity.reporting-org: The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria
iati-activity.title: Africa, Asia, Latin America and Caribbean, Eastern Europe""Compassion, Conversion, Care; Responding as Churches to the HIV/AIDS Pandemic""
iati-activity.description: The main objective of the program supported by this grant is to encage church leaders (particularly bishops, youth and women leaders) and other relevant individuals around the world, regardless of their religious affiliation, more actively in the fight against the HIV pandemic; to educate them about the role their churches can play in combating the pandemic in their country settings; to help progressive youth and women leaders guiding the member churches in their fight against HIV to work toward a much more active and open involvement in HIV and AIDS work; and to encourage and support member churches and other institutions in becoming cooperating partners of host-country Country Coordinating Mechanisms.

conditions.condition:
COS Special Condition 7 - The Principal Recipient acknowledges and agrees that the Global Fund may at its sole discretion undertake direct payment of grant funds to third parties (e.g., French Red Cross) for Program purposes. The Principal Recipient further acknowledges and agrees that:
(i) the Principal Recipient continues to be responsible for ensuring that all health products purchased with grant funds, including those paid by direct payment to third parties, comply with the Global Fund’s procurement policies (including the Quality Assurance Policy) and the approved Procurement and Supply Management Plan for the grant; and
(ii) the Principal Recipient is fully liable for all transactions with any procurement agent, supplier or manufacturer

COS Special Condition 8 - The Principal Recipient acknowledges and agrees to report, in collaboration with the Sub-Recipient, on a monthly basis to the Global Fund on programmatic achievements and financial expenditures during the course of the Program.

COS Special Condition 9 - The Principal Recipient acknowledges and agrees that prior to the use of Grant funds for the procurement of Health Products other than pharmaceuticals, such as reagents and consumables, in Year 2 of the Continuity of Services Program, the Principal Recipient will provide evidence, in form and substance satisfactory to the Global Fund, that the storage conditions and capacity of the identified warehouse and cold room for storage of Health Products are adequate and in compliance with best practice.

COS Special Condition 10 - The Principal Recipient acknowledges and agrees that prior to any purchase of nutritional kits during the entire term of the Program, the Principal Recipient shall provide to the Global Fund, in form and substance satisfactory to the Global Fund, a detailed breakdown of the costs of such purchase of nutritional kits. Such cost breakdown shall include, but will not be limited to, a description of each of the unit cost of the food and the cost of the transport of the nutritional kits.

The Principal Recipient shall provide to the satisfaction of the Global Fund:


1. A fully costed plan to improve the TSR and address the high default rate within a maximum implementation timeframe of one year; and
2. Revised grant documents including: (i)a revised program budget to incorporate the plan (which includes correct cost category classifications in accordance with the Global Fund budgeting guidelines); and (ii) workplan, performance framework, technical assistance and training plans and PSM Plan, aligned with the revised program budget.

The Principal Recipient  shall provide evidence satisfactory to the Global Fund that the Principal Recipient has entered into a Memorandum of Understanding with the WHO setting out  a detailed workplan specifying  the deliverables and detailed assumptions  for TA to be provided or arranged by the WHO.

The Principal Recipient shall provide to the satisfaction of the Global Fund:

1. an update on inventory-on- hand, planned procurements and related procurement and delivery timelines; and
2. an update on the implementation of  Standard Operating Procedures for the management of the procurement and distribution of Health Products, in accordance with the requirements, policies  and  guidelines  of the Global Fund.

The Principal Recipient shall provide to the satisfaction of the Global Fund:


1. A fully costed plan to improve the TSR and address the high default rate within a maximum implementation timeframe of one year; and
2. Revised grant documents including: (i)a revised program budget to incorporate the plan (which includes correct cost category classifications in accordance with the Global Fund budgeting guidelines); and (ii) workplan, performance framework, technical assistance and training plans and PSM Plan, aligned with the revised program budget.

The Principal Recipient  shall provide evidence satisfactory to the Global Fund that the Principal Recipient has entered into a Memorandum of Understanding with the WHO setting out  a detailed workplan specifying  the deliverables and detailed assumptions  for TA to be provided or arranged by the WHO.

The Principal Recipient shall provide to the satisfaction of the Global Fund:

1. an update on inventory-on- hand, planned procurements and related procurement and delivery timelines; and
2. an update on the implementation of  Standard Operating Procedures for the management of the procurement and distribution of Health Products, in accordance with the requirements, policies  and  guidelines  of the Global Fund.

The Principal Recipient shall provide to the satisfaction of the Global Fund:


1. A fully costed plan to improve the TSR and address the high default rate within a maximum implementation timeframe of one year; and
2. Revised grant documents including: (i)a revised program budget to incorporate the plan (which includes correct cost category classifications in accordance with the Global Fund budgeting guidelines); and (ii) workplan, performance framework, technical assistance and training plans and PSM Plan, aligned with the revised program budget.

The Principal Recipient  shall provide evidence satisfactory to the Global Fund that the Principal Recipient has entered into a Memorandum of Understanding with the WHO setting out  a detailed workplan specifying  the deliverables and detailed assumptions  for TA to be provided or arranged by the WHO.

The Principal Recipient shall provide to the satisfaction of the Global Fund:

1. an update on inventory-on- hand, planned procurements and related procurement and delivery timelines; and
2. an update on the implementation of  Standard Operating Procedures for the management of the procurement and distribution of Health Products, in accordance with the requirements, policies  and  guidelines  of the Global Fund.

CP1 - Condition precedent to the third disbursement a) The delivery by the Principal Recipient to the Global Fund of a revised plan for monitoring and evaluating Program activities (the "Updated M&E Plan"), in form and substance satisfactory to the Global Fund, covering the period from 1 January 2012 to 31 December 2014 and including all activities undertaken as part of the consolidation of the SSF grant with the TFM; and 1b- The delivery by the Principal Recipient to the Global Fund of a revised budget for the Program Term (the "Revised Program Budget") if the amendments in the Updated M&E Plan necessitate amendments to the budget approved by the Global Fund as of the effective date of this Agreement.

2nd Impl Period: STC 1. The Principal Recipient shall cooperate with the relevant office of the Green Light Committee (the "GLC") in the GLC’s efforts to provide support to the Principal Recipient with respect to the implementation, management and monitoring of the MDR-TB-related services provided in-country and any needed scale-up of such services. Accordingly, the Principal Recipient shall budget and authorize the Global Fund to disburse up to a maximum of US$ 50,000, or a lower amount as agreed with GLC and the Global Fund, each year to pay for GLC services.

2nd Impl Period: STC 2. By no later than one month after the start of the Implementation Period, the Principal Recipients shall submit a Joint Program Implementation Plan, developed together with the Ministry of Health, which describes the roles and responsibilities of Principal Recipients, Sub-recipients, and States at the federal, state and Local Government Area level, and which describes how the Principal Recipients will improve the linkage and referral system between State Tuberculosis and Leprosy Control officers, community systems (Community Based Organizations and Community Volunteers) and health facilities to increase case detection and notification rates.

2nd Impl Period: STC 3. By no later than 15 February 2013, the Principal Recipient shall submit to the Global Fund a strategy (the State MOU Strategy), in form and substance satisfactory to the Global Fund, that describes how the Principal Recipient will ensure that it will enter into, by no later than 30 June 2013, memoranda of understanding with all States that shall describe: the agreed implementation and funding arrangements between the Principal Recipient and each State; the roles and responsibilities of the Principal Recipient, the State, Sub-Recipients and partners, including how interventions will be aligned and coordinated; and the roles and responsibilities of the Principal Recipient and the State for inventory and supply chain management at the State level. The State MOU Strategy shall also describe how the Principal Recipient intends to begin tracking expenditures for related TB programs at the State level, including any proposed initiatives or related studies. The State MOU Strategy shall be accompanied by the Principal Recipient’s proposal for funding supporting activities to meet this condition, which may include the proposed use of savings from other budget lines under this Agreement.

2nd Imp Period: STC 4. On a semi-annual basis and as an attachment to each disbursement request to the Global Fund, the Principal Recipient shall provide to the Global Fund a brief report, in form and substance satisfactory to the Global Fund, issued by the Principal Recipient’s Internal Audit department, on the oversight of the Program at the Principal Recipient and Sub-recipient level. Such a report shall include, but not be limited to, any issues identified in the previous quarter, including, appropriate action plans to address the identified or potential weaknesses in the financial, accounting, procurement or management systems and shall describe progress made in mitigating these weaknesses.

indicator.title: "Percentage of TB patients with known HIV status "

Percentage of STI cases treated according to national guidelines

iati-activity.reporting-org: The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria
iati-activity.title: National Response to HIV/AIDS in Malawi
iati-activity.description: Malawi is among the countries in Southern Africa at the epicenters of the HIV and AIDS pandemic, with HIV infection predominantly transmitted through heterosexual intercourse. The program supported by this grant aims to bring a balanced approach between prevention, care, support and treatment of HIV and AIDS in Malawi and to reduce the burden of HIV and AIDS-related illnesses and deaths so that they no longer pose a threat to economic growth and political stability. The program consists of assistance to expand voluntary counseling and testing centers, to provide services to HIV-infected mothers to prevention transmission of the disease to their infants; and commencement of antiretroviral therapy to eligible patients. The program is also strengthening home-based care and treatment of opportunistic infections.

contact-info.organisation: The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria

iati-activity.participating-org: The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria
National AIDS Commission, Malawi

conditions.condition: The delivery of evidence that a stock count of RDTs purchased with Grant Funds has been undertaken. This stock count shall etablish whether existing RDT stock and number of RDTs budgeted for under phase 2 are sufficient to support the number of anticiopated tests under Phase 2

No later than six weeks after the effective date of the Phase 2 extension, the Principal Recipient shall deliver: - clarifications on the assumptions underlying the calculation of ACT needs for adults and children; and - accurate and exhaustive figures detailing the additional sources of funding for the Program

The Principal Recipient understands that the Global Fund will assess Program progress and performance in detail at the end of Year 3 and then decide whether to continue to support the Program or to discontinue the funding .

IP 1: The use of Grant funds for the procurement of any Health Products shall be subject to the delivery by the Principal Recipient to the Global Fund of evidence, in form and substance satisfactory to the Global Fund, that the Principal Recipient has selected and employed suitably qualified and experienced staff or enlisted appropriate technical assistance to procure Pharmaceuticals and Health Products (as defined in Article 19 of the Standard Terms and Conditions of this Agreement) in relation to the scope and performance of the Program (including without limitation, to improve the capacity of the Principal Recipient to quantify and forecast the demand and use of Health Products under the Program).

IP 1: No later than 31 March 2011, and in coordination with other principal recipients of Global Fund grant programs in Sierra Leone, the Principal Recipient shall to the satisfaction of the Global Fund complete the Sections of the Pharmaceutical and Health Products Country Profile for Sierra Leone (the "Country Profile") that are incomplete and/or incorrect and submit the Country Profile as one consolidated document. The Principal Recipient shall also no later than 31 March 2011 submit in form and substance satisfactory to the Global Fund an Action Plan relating to addressing the issues raised in the Country Profile to the Global Fund for review.

IP 1: No later than 31 December 2011, in coordination with other principal recipients of Global Fund grant programs in Sierra Leone, the Principal Recipient shall promptly arrange the establishment of a formal Pharmaceutical and Health Product Management (PHPM) coordination committee under the umbrella of the Principal Recipient’s coordination involving the different stakeholders with Terms of Reference satisfactory to the Global Fund to address PHPM issues related to programs supported through Global Fund financing.

IP 1: The Principal Recipient shall ensure that an adequate supply chain is being used for all Pharmaceutical and Health Products funded by the Global Fund that is in compliance with the WHO Guidelines for Good Storage Practices and Good Distribution Practices for Health Products.

IP 1: The use of Grant funds for the payment of salaries to Health Workers (the "HW Payments") shall be subject to the delivery by the Principal Recipient to the Global Fund of evidence, in form and substance satisfactory to the Global Fund, that the Principal Recipient has entered into a Memorandum of Understanding satisfactory to the Global Fund (the "MoU") together with the Ministry of Health, DFID and the Ministry of Finance, detailing the implementation and coordination of responsibilities under the Program, terms and conditions of their collaboration and defining the roles and responsibilities of each party. In particular, the MoU shall include safeguards to ensure the coordination and management of all funding sources relating to HW Payments and the time intervals (every 2 months) at which the Principal Recipient may transfer funds to a pooled HW Payment account, and ensure that all risks relating to the operation of the HW Payment account and the management and administration of the pooled HP Payment account and the making of HW Payments are mitigated. The Principal Recipient shall ensure complete and accurate records of all payments to and from the pooled HP Payment account. If at the end of the Program Term there are any surplus funds in the pooled HP Payment account, they must be promptly distributed by the Principal Recipient to all relevant funding sources in the same proportion as the total amount of the relevant contributions of the funding sources at the time of distribution. The Principal Recipient shall use its best efforts to ensure that the contributions of the Global Fund to HW Payments are replaced by other funding sources by the end of the Program Term.

IP 1: The Principal Recipient acknowledges that the CCM for Sierra Leone is required to promptly submit to the Global Fund a revised remuneration scale for the HSS component of the Program to cover the potential 5 year duration of the Program. The Principal Recipient shall use its best endeavors to ensure that the CCM meets this obligation.

IP 1: During Program implementation, the Principal Recipient shall provide evidence to the Global Fund, in form and substance satisfactory to the Global Fund, that the Principal Recipient is conducting regular follow-up activities on its Plan of Action regarding MSM. Such Plan of Action shall be implemented in collaboration with the CCM for Sierra Leone and the DIGNITY ASSOCIATION (association of MSM) who have agreed to jointly address the stigma and discrimination of MSM.

IP 1: During Program implementation, the Principal Recipient shall in collaboration with the CCM pro-actively and regularly organize review meetings with its partners, to discuss Program implementation such as to identify and address implementation bottlenecks. Detailed minutes of such meetings shall be prepared and upon request, promptly disclosed to the Global Fund.

IP 1: The use by the Principal Recipient of Grant funds to finance training programs is subject to the satisfaction of each of the following conditions:
i. the delivery by the Principal Recipient to the Global Fund of the detailed plan and the detailed budget related to the trainings that will be conducted (the "Detailed Training Plan and Budget"). In particular such a plan shall demonstrate that no duplication of training activities will occur, that trainings are linked to Program’s objectives, that the quality of trainings is assessed and that cash transactions related to cost of organization and per diems are limited whenever possible; and
ii. the written approval by the Global Fund of the Detailed Training Plan and Budget.

The disbursement of Grant funds by the Global Fund to the Principal Recipient for Sub-Recipient activities is subject to the delivery by the Principal Recipient to the Global Fund of evidence, in form and substance satisfactory to the Global Fund, that the Principal Recipient has assessed the Sub-Recipient to determine its capacity to manage grant activities, finances and reporting.

The Principal Recipient shall provide to the Global Fund, in form and substance satisfactory to the Global Fund, draft versions of the PMTCT and VCT baseline studies prior to the release of funding for PMTCT and VCT programme evaluations. In addition, the Principal Recipient shall provide evidence to the Global Fund, in form and substance satisfactory to the Global Fund, that PMTCT and VCT programme evaluations are on track for completion prior to the Phase 2 review of the Grant by the Global Fund.

iati-activity.reporting-org: The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria
iati-activity.title: Accelerating the Implementation of new anti-malarial treatment policy artemesinin based combination therapy (ACTs) and scaling up access to LLINs within the context of the Sector Wide Approach
iati-activity.description: Malaria is a serious public health problem in Malawi, with the entire population being at risk for the disease. The program supported by this grant aims to accelerate the implementation of the country’s new antimalarial treatment policy. Program objectives include rapidly scaling up access to prompt and effective treatment of malaria cases with artemisinin-based combination therapy within 24 hours of onset of fever at a health facility and increasing coverage of children under age five and pregnant women with long-lasting insecticide-treated bed nets.

contact-info.organisation: The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria

iati-activity.participating-org: The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria
Ministry of Health of Malawi

conditions.condition: The Principal Recipient shall deliver to the Global Fund, in form and substance satisfactory to the Global Fund, a Quality Assurance Plan (QAP). The QAP shall clearly describe the measures to be taken to monitor and ensure the quality of pharmaceuticals, from the moment of purchase to consumption by the end user. A work plan and a budget should be added. The QA budget should be based on 3% of the EwX drug costs (QC budget around 1%). This line should be included in the detailed budget.

The Principal Recipient shall develop, with the support of international technical assistance (if needed), and deliver evidence to the Global Fund of:
1) a guide and/or specific Standard Operational Procedures (SOPs), in form and substance satisfactory to the Global Fund, related to storage conditions and drug management for health facilities; and
2) a plan for dissemination and implementation of such guide and/or SOPs, and for training of health facility staff for implementation.

The Principal Recipient shall deliver to the Global Fund, in form and substance satisfactory to the Global Fund, an updated national M&E Plan in line with the final Performance Framework and budget for Phase 2, which shall include M&E activities supported by the National Program and other partners.

The Principal Recipient shall take appropriate measures to improve the estimation of TB burden in Benin, including (i) completing a comprehensive assessment of the TB surveillance systems to measure the completeness of the TB notification system and (ii) engaging with WHO and other key partners to improve and agree on the current estimates of TB burden in the country. With each PU/DR, the Principal Recipient shall deliver a written update to the Global Fund on the progress made in improving TB estimates and M&E capacity at district levels.

The Principal Recipient shall develop and deliver to the Global Fund an action plan to strengthen coverage and reach of the TB diagnostic services. Such action plan shall clearly define measures to be undertaken by the national TB program, in collaboration with partners, to:
1) Review current diagnostic capacity and quality, and improve access to diagnostic services through expansion of smear microscopy and use of new diagnostics;
2) Ensure compliance to national guidelines for diagnosis of smear negative TB and childhood TB; and
3) Focus case finding efforts for identified key populations at increased risk or areas/ regions with poor programmatic performance.

The Principal Recipient shall deliver to the Global Fund, in form and substance satisfactory to the Global Fund, an updated Comprehensive Manual of Procedures. The Comprehensive Manual of Procedures shall include a detailed description of the Principal Recipient’s policies and procedures and any other policies and procedures relevant to the management of Grant funds, including, without limitation, the following:
a. accounting and financial procedures (including inventory, asset management and cash management which includes petty cash ceilings);
b. human resources policies and procedures (including an updated organigram, salary scales and per diem);
c. procurement policy and procedures; and
d. code of ethics including a conflict of interest policy and a whistleblowing policy, ensuring that adequate mechanisms are in place for proper segregation of duties and that internal controls are in place within the Program Management Unit of the Principal Recipient.

The Principal Recipient shall deliver to the Global Fund, in form and substance satisfactory to the Global Fund, a risk based audit plan to improve financial management and internal control in the implementation of the Grant.

The Principal Recipient shall deliver to the Global Fund, in form and substance satisfactory to the Global Fund, a revised PSM plan. The PSM plan shall address concerns regarding procurement, Inventory Management and Quality Assurance, including absence of clear forecasting assumptions, uncertainty regarding the Category 2 continuation phase regimen and discrepancies in unit prices.
The PSM Plan shall be consistent with the work plan & budget and all assumptions used to determine the quantities of health products shall be clearly documented, including, where applicable, the link to the targets in the Performance Framework.

The Principal Recipient shall deliver to the Global Fund, in form and substance satisfactory to the Global Fund, a Quality Assurance Plan (QAP). The QAP shall clearly describe the measures to be taken to monitor and ensure the quality of pharmaceuticals, from the moment of purchase to consumption by the end user. A work plan and a budget should be added. The QA budget should be based on 3% of the EwX drug costs (QC budget around 1%). This line should be included in the detailed budget.

The Principal Recipient shall develop, with the support of international technical assistance (if needed), and deliver evidence to the Global Fund of:
1) a guide and/or specific Standard Operational Procedures (SOPs), in form and substance satisfactory to the Global Fund, related to storage conditions and drug management for health facilities; and
2) a plan for dissemination and implementation of such guide and/or SOPs, and for training of health facility staff for implementation.

The Principal Recipient shall deliver to the Global Fund, in form and substance satisfactory to the Global Fund, an updated national M&E Plan in line with the final Performance Framework and budget for Phase 2, which shall include M&E activities supported by the National Program and other partners.

The Principal Recipient shall take appropriate measures to improve the estimation of TB burden in Benin, including (i) completing a comprehensive assessment of the TB surveillance systems to measure the completeness of the TB notification system and (ii) engaging with WHO and other key partners to improve and agree on the current estimates of TB burden in the country. With each PU/DR, the Principal Recipient shall deliver a written update to the Global Fund on the progress made in improving TB estimates and M&E capacity at district levels.

iati-activity.reporting-org: The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria
iati-activity.title: Orphan Care and Support (HIV/AIDS)
iati-activity.description: Although the HIV and AIDS prevalence rate seems to have stabilized in Malawi, the number of orphans and vulnerable children will increase. The program supported by this grant aims to reach aims to strengthen and develop an enabling policy and legal framework to protect the rights of orphans and other children who have been made vulnerable by HIV and AIDS and poverty; strengthen institutions and technical capacity at all levels to ensure a rapid scale up of the national response to the orphan crisis, giving particular attention o district and community capacity and systems; and increase access of orphans and vulnerable children to primary and secondary education and other services with support from the safety nets providing school bursaries and cash transfers to households caring for orphans and vulnerable children.

contact-info.organisation: The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria

iati-activity.participating-org: The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria
National AIDS Commission, Malawi

conditions.condition: Special Terms and Conditions: STC 1. The Internal Audit unit of the Principal Recipient shall conduct at least one internal audit per Province annually, covering all Global Fund programs in the each given Province. The focus of the internal audit should ensure that sufficient audit work is carried out on the following areas at a minimum: asset management, cash control including cash allowances to staff and clients, external auditor selection, procurement processes as well as SR/SSR selection and oversight arrangements which shall include contracting of civil society and other community-based organizations. The audit work will also include examination of controls of a number of prefectures and counties as part of the Provincial Audit. Any issues identified and recommendations made shall be addressed by the Principal Recipient in a timely basismanner. The Principal Recipient will be required to report with each Progress Update and Disbursement Request, the number of audits completed, issues raised and status of management actions to address the issues identified.shall cease on 30 September 2012. The Principal Recipient further agrees that the Program shall be subject to a mid-term review no later than 30 September 2012.
